h3: What are they? Why do we even use chars?!
p: Strings are everywhere in computers. Every message you read, every button you click, even this text right now — all stored as strings. A string is basically a collection of characters grouped together in a safe, easy-to-use way. In C++, a string looks like this:
p1: "But we don’t learn this in high-school!" True. In school we usually start with the most low-level form of text storage — chars. Long before the modern std::string existed, programmers used char arrays to store text. And because of something called Backward Compatibility, modern C++ still lets us use many string functions on these old char arrays.

p4: Before we move on, just a small heads-up: from here on, we’ll explore functions made for std::string that also work on char arrays thanks to backward compatibility. I’ll explain everything in a simple and friendly way, but you should already know a little bit of C++ basics — things like variables, arrays, #include, and std::cout. Don’t worry, I won’t throw anything impossible at you, but this isn’t meant for total beginners either.
